THE CHAIRMAN : Right. I would like to welcome t oday Mr. Svendsen of Norway, who has been appointed Alternate Executive Director by Mr.
Beyen. He came in after the meeting started so I didn't have a chance to introduce him before. We are glad to have
you here. I would like to just take a few minutes to tell you of
another matter -- some discussions which have been going
on in a tentative way and which Mr. Black expects to carry forward in Brussels regarding a possible prospective
loan to Belgium, the Bel gian Congo. I will ask Mr. Iliff if he would be kind enough to outline to you what up to
n ow has been put forward as a line of approach. MR. ILIFF: Mr. Chairman, the Board will remember that in March of 1949 we entered into a loan contrac t with the Kingdom of Belgium for a 16 million dollar loan, of whic the proceeds were to be expended in financing the foreign
exchange costs of imports required to develop two Belgian
steel mills and a power project .
Very soon after that loan was made, we were approached
by the Belgian Gove~nment with a proposal for another loan
to the Kingdom of Bel gium. The justification advanced by  23 STRICTLY CONFIDENTIAL the Belgian Government for that operation in the view of
the President was not adequate to warrant him recommending
it to the Board.
Subsequently, we had a. further approach from the
Belgian Ministry of the Colonies, who raised with the
International Bank the possibility of a loan to assist in
financing a development program in the Belgian Congo. That
is a ten-year program whose estimated cost amounts to a
very large sum of money.
The Bank in response to that approach indicated its
interest in principle in participating in financing such a
program. Further discussions took place with the Belgian
authorities in the course of which it emerged that the
Belgian Government would find some difficulty in guarantee-
ing an International Bank loan to the Belgian Congo unless
the Bank operation made some recognition of the impact of
the Congo development program in terms of foreign exchange on
the economy of metropolitan Belgium itself.
Now, this impact arises from the fact that a very sub-
stantial part of the import requirements of the Congo
program will be procured in metropolitan Belgium. This will
lead to a large expansion of Belgian incomes. And if infla-
tion is to be avoided, this increase in Belgian incomes will
increase Belgium's need to use foreign exchange for imports
into Belgium itself partly in the form of raw materials,  24 STRICTLY CONFIDENTIAL partly in the form of components and partly in the form of
consumer goods.
The management of the Bank feels, therefore, that
there are valid economic reasons for approaching the problem
of Bank participation in the Congo development program with
two principles in mind. The first would be the possibility
of financing to the extent necessary the foreign exchange
costs, direct and indirect, of imports into the Congo from
sources other than the Belgian franc area, and secondly
a recognition of the impact of the Congo development program
on the foreign exchange resources of metropolitan Belgium
herself.
Accordingly, the President, who as Mr. Garner says ex-
pects to be in Brussels early next week, proposes to under-
take discussions with the Belgian Government leading towards
a possible International Bank operation to assist in the
financing of the Congo development program based upon the two principles that I have just mentioned.
The Congo plan is a ten-year plan. Up to now, only the
program for the first three-year phase has been worked out
with any degree of definitiveness. At this stage, therefore,
any Bank financing would be related to the three-year
program. And j f the Board 'vould care to have some general
jnformation as to what is involved in this three-year
program, I think Mr. Garner will ask Mr. Kamarck in a fewÂ·  25 STRICTLY CONFIDENTIAL minutes to give some information on that point.
The total cost of the three-yearÂ· progre.m in dollar
equivalents will be about 240 millions. Of this, local
savings can cover local expenditures -- and when I talk
of local savings I mean local savings in the Congo itself
can coverâ€¢ local expenditures to the extent of the
equivalent of 68 million dollars, which leaves 172 million
dollars to be obtained from outside the Congo.
Now, of that 172 million it is calculated that the equivalent of 98 million dollars will be required for im-
ports from outside the Belgian franc area. The Belgian
authorities already have foreign financing in sight to the
extent of approximately 55 to 60 million dollars. So there
is a gap of approximately 40 million dollars to meet the
actual foreign exchange costs of the imports into the Congo
itself other than from the Belgian franc area. And it
would be a figure of that order which might constitute the
amount of the Bank's contribution directly to the Congo.
I should say at this stage, sir, that that figure
that I mentioned is approximate, and ,.,e shall still have to
have rurther discussions with the Belgian authorities before
we can arrive at a definitive amount.
As regards metropolitan Belgium, we calculate from
the information that we have before us that the Congo will
import directly from Belgium a very substantial quantity of  26 STRICTLY CONFIDENTIAL Belgian production. It will probably be equivalent to some-
thing of the order of 75 million dollars.
Now, the addition to Belgian incomes ~rhich ~rill apise
from this impact on Belgian production will very much exceed
that amount of 75 mill:l.on dollars. The actual impact on ;j If the Belgian foreign exchange reserves has yet to be worked II d 11 out. It will require detailed study by the Bank staff in II I 1l consultation with Belgian economists. So, at this stage
I am not able to indicate what the order of magnitude of
that impact might be. I should say, however, that it would
be the management's proposal to finance only the foreign
exchange cost to metropolitan Belgium to the extent that
they may be involved in gold or dollars.
The whole justification for this combined operation
l:tes in the desirability of furthering economic development
in the Belgian Congo, and the Bank would therefore look
for assurances from the Belgian Government that the goods
of Belgian origin actually needed for the Congo development
program will be made available from the production potential
of the metropole.
I should add too that when I mention this three-year
program of investment in the Belgian Congo as costing some-
thing like 240 million dollars, or equivalent, that we are
taking into consideration only investment in the public
sector. It is expected that there will be a very substantia  27 STRICTLY CONFIDENTIAL additional amount of investment in the private sector~ which
again will have its impact on metropolitan Belgium in the
same directions as I have indicated for the investment in
the public sector. So that by taking into account only the
effects of investment in the public sector~ we are being
conservative in our assessment of the impact on Belgium's
foreign exchange position.
The setup of this operation~ if it comes to fruition~
is a matter for fUrther study. The mechanics can be worked
out in a variety of ways~ and we have not yet come to any
firm conclusion as to how the operation shall be set up.
At this stage~ the management wish to inform the Board of
the principles of the approach which might be adopted by
the President in his forthcoming talks in Brussels.
I think I ought to add this, sir: That from the point
of view of creditworthiness, the staff are satisfied that
whatever the amount that we are thinking of at the moment
may be, it will be well within Belgium's capacity to repay.

ly.

doc.abstracts: According to this transcript, in March 1949, the Bank entered into a loan agreement with the Kingdom of Belgium for a loan in the amount of 16 million dollars. The proceeds of this loan were to be applied to meeting the foreign exchange cost of equipment to be imported into Belgium for the expansion of two Belgian steel mills and a power plant. In response to the approach of the Belgian ministry of the Colonies, the Bank indicated its interest, in principle, in participating in the financing of such a program. Further discussions took place with the Belgian authorities, in the course of which it emerged that the Belgian government will find some difficulty in guaranteeing any International Bank loan to the Belgian Congo unless the operation to be undertaken by the Bank made some recognition of the impact of the Congo development program in terms of foreign exchange, on the economy of metropolitan Belgium itself. The management feels that there are valid economic arguments for approaching the question of possible Bank participation in the Congo development program with two principles in minds: first, financing by the Bank, to the extent necessary, the direct and indirect foreign exchange costs of imports into the Congo from sources other than the Belgian franc area; and second, a recognition of the impact of the Congo's development program on the foreign exchange resources of metropolitan Belgium.
